content: The "Reforming Alternatives to Incarceration and Sentencing to Establish a Better Path for Youth Act of 2015" is also known as the "RAISE Act of 2015." It includes a safety valve for nonviolent youth. Section 3553 of title 18, United States Code, can now allow courts to impose a sentence below a statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it would result in substantial injustice to the youth. This change is part of the "RAISE Act of 2015." The court can impose a sentence below the statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it is not necessary for public protection. Parties must be given notice and an opportunity to respond. The court must state the reasons for the sentence in writing. Appeal rights are not limited. The Youth Sentencing Reform Act allows for sentences below the statutory minimum for individuals under 21 years old convicted of nonviolent federal offenses, excluding crimes of violence or sex offenses. The Youth Sentencing Reform Act allows for early release and home confinement for youth under 21 convicted of nonviolent federal offenses, excluding violent or sex crimes. Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow for early release and home confinement for prisoners, with specific conditions outlined for the duration of home confinement based on the term of imprisonment. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for youth prisoners to be placed in home confinement for a specific duration based on their term of imprisonment. There is a presumption in favor of direct release to home confinement, unless specific findings are made by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons that resources from a community correction center are necessary for the prisoner's reentry into the community. Placement in a community correction center cannot be used solely due to a mental health diagnosis. The amendment allows youth prisoners to be placed in home confinement for a specific duration based on their term of imprisonment. The Bureau of Prisons must release a youth who has served half or more of their sentence for a nonviolent offense and has not violated any terms. The amendment allows youth prisoners to be placed in home confinement if they have served half or more of their sentence for a nonviolent offense and have not violated any institutional disciplinary regulations involving violent conduct in the last 2 years. The amendment allows youth prisoners to be considered for supervised release if they have served half or more of their sentence for a nonviolent offense and have not violated any institutional disciplinary regulations involving violent conduct in the last 2 years. The amendment allows for supervised release of youth prisoners after serving at least 20 years of their sentence, considering certain factors, including nonviolent offenses and disciplinary behavior. The amendment allows for supervised release of youth prisoners after serving at least 20 years of their sentence, based on extraordinary and compelling reasons, rehabilitation efforts, and a determination of not being a danger to others by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons. The amendment to Section 3581 of title 18, United States Code, introduces a provision for a discretionary life sentence for youth offenders convicted of crimes carrying a mandatory life term. The term 'youth' refers to individuals aged 21 or younger at the time of the offense. SMARTER PROBATION FOR YOUTH. In General, Section 3565 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a Special Rule for Technical Violations, limiting imprisonment to 30, 60, or 90 days for first, second, or subsequent violations during probation. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for probation and supervised release revocation under section 3565 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 6. SPECIALIZED HOUSING AND PROGRAMS FOR YOUTH. Section 4042(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to designate correctional facilities for youth separate from other offenders and to establish education, skills training, and reentry programs. Establish education, skills training, reentry, and mental health programs tailored to the needs of youth. Establish pilot programs for youth. The Bureau of Prisons will establish pilot programs for youth in at least 10 judicial districts, including mentorship and government service initiatives. The mentorship program will pair youth with formerly incarcerated individuals or volunteers from faith-based or community organizations. The government service program will provide skills training and internships for youth. The Attorney General will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth to avoid criminal conviction, including specialized training for animals seized by law enforcement and organizations that care for vulnerable animals. The Attorney General will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth to avoid criminal conviction through intensive case management and comprehensive community services, including specialized training for animals seized by law enforcement and organizations that care for vulnerable animals. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the results of pilot programs for high-risk youth, including cost savings, participant numbers, and recidivism rates. Definitions include "youth" as individuals 21 years or younger at the time of the offense, and "nonviolent offense" as federal crimes excluding violence or sex offenses. The curr_chunk states that a sex offense is defined in section 111 of the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act (42 U.S.C. 16911). The Act and its amendments apply to youth involved in the Federal criminal justice system regardless of when they become involved.
